questions.question: For 2024, the annual gift tax exclusion per donee is:
questions.explanation: For 2024, the annual gift tax exclusion is $18,000 per donee. This amount is indexed for inflation and increased from $17,000 in 2023. A donor can give up to this amount to any number of recipients without using any of their lifetime exemption or filing a gift tax return.
questions.tip: The annual exclusion increases periodically with inflation. Know the current year's amount for the exam.

questions.question: When a married couple elects gift splitting, the maximum annual exclusion available for a gift to one donee from one spouse is:
questions.explanation: Gift splitting allows married couples to treat a gift made by one spouse as made one-half by each spouse. With the 2024 annual exclusion of $18,000 per spouse, a married couple can give up to $36,000 per donee ($18,000 × 2) without any gift tax consequences.
questions.tip: Gift splitting requires both spouses to consent and both must file gift tax returns even if only one spouse made the gift.

questions.question: The unified credit exemption amount for estate tax purposes in 2024 is approximately:

options.A: $5.49 million
options.B: $11.58 million
options.C: $12.92 million
options.D: $13.61 million

questions.explanation: For 2024, the basic exclusion amount (unified credit exemption) is $13.61 million. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act doubled the exemption through 2025, after which it is scheduled to revert to approximately $5-6 million (adjusted for inflation) unless Congress acts.
questions.tip: The exemption is unified for gift and estate tax purposes—lifetime gifts reduce the amount available at death.

questions.question: In 2024, Sarah gives $25,000 cash to her nephew. What is Sarah's taxable gift?
questions.explanation: The taxable gift is the total gift minus the annual exclusion: $25,000 - $18,000 = $7,000. The $7,000 taxable gift will reduce Sarah's lifetime exemption but no gift tax will be owed unless the lifetime exemption has been exhausted.
questions.tip: Taxable gift = Total gift - Annual exclusion. The annual exclusion applies per donee.

questions.question: For estate tax purposes, the marital deduction for property left to a surviving spouse who is a U.S. citizen is:

options.A: Limited to $500,000
options.B: Limited to the unified credit amount
options.C: Unlimited
options.D: 50% of the estate

questions.explanation: The marital deduction is unlimited for transfers to a surviving spouse who is a U.S. citizen. This means a decedent can leave any amount to a surviving spouse without incurring estate tax. If the spouse is not a U.S. citizen, the unlimited deduction generally is not available unless a Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT) is used.
questions.tip: The unlimited marital deduction defers estate tax until the surviving spouse dies—it doesn't eliminate the tax entirely.

questions.question: The annual gift tax exclusion is available only for gifts of:

options.A: Cash only
options.B: Future interests
options.C: Present interests
options.D: Revocable transfers

questions.explanation: The annual exclusion applies only to gifts of present interests—rights to immediate use, possession, or enjoyment. Future interests, where the donee's enjoyment is delayed, do not qualify for the annual exclusion. This is why gifts to trusts often require special provisions (like Crummey powers) to qualify.
questions.tip: Crummey powers give beneficiaries a temporary withdrawal right, converting a future interest to a present interest.

questions.question: Which of the following payments qualifies for unlimited exclusion from gift tax without using any annual exclusion?

options.A: Payment of a grandchild's living expenses while in college
options.B: Payment directly to a grandchild to reimburse tuition costs
options.C: Payment directly to a medical provider for a friend's surgery
options.D: Payment to a family member for nursing home care

questions.explanation: Qualified transfers for medical expenses are unlimited exclusions if paid directly to the medical provider. Living expenses and tuition reimbursements to the individual don't qualify. Medical payments must go directly to the provider, not to the patient or a family member for reimbursement.
questions.tip: Qualified medical and educational exclusions require DIRECT payment to the provider/institution—not to the person.

questions.question: A gift tax return (Form 709) must be filed when:

options.A: Any gift is made during the year
options.B: Gifts to any one donee exceed the annual exclusion
options.C: Total gifts during the year exceed $18,000
options.D: Gift splitting is elected regardless of amount

questions.explanation: A gift tax return must be filed when: (1) gifts to any one donee exceed the annual exclusion, (2) gift splitting is elected (even if total gifts are under the exclusion), (3) gifts of future interests are made, or (4) gifts to a non-citizen spouse exceed the annual exclusion for such gifts ($185,000 in 2024).
questions.tip: Gift splitting always requires filing by both spouses, even if no taxable gift results.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in a decedent's gross estate?

options.A: Life insurance proceeds on decedent's life payable to a named beneficiary when decedent held no incidents of ownership
options.B: Property transferred to an irrevocable trust 5 years before death with no retained interests
options.C: Life insurance proceeds on decedent's life payable to the estate
options.D: Qualified charitable remainder trust assets

questions.explanation: Life insurance proceeds are included in the gross estate if payable to the estate or if the decedent held any incidents of ownership in the policy. Life insurance payable to named beneficiaries where the decedent held no incidents of ownership is excluded. Irrevocable transfers without retained interests made more than 3 years before death are also excluded.
questions.tip: Incidents of ownership include the right to change beneficiaries, borrow against the policy, or surrender for cash value.

questions.question: Which of the following expenses is deductible for estate tax purposes?

options.A: Federal income taxes on income earned after death
options.B: State inheritance taxes paid by beneficiaries
options.C: Attorney fees for estate administration
options.D: Expenses of the decedent's last illness paid after death if claimed on the final Form 1040

questions.explanation: Administration expenses, including attorney fees, executor commissions, and court costs, are deductible from the gross estate. These cannot be deducted on both the estate tax return and the estate's income tax return. Medical expenses paid after death can be deducted on the estate return OR the decedent's final income tax return, but not both.
questions.tip: Double deduction is prohibited—expenses deducted on Form 706 cannot also be deducted on the estate's Form 1041.

questions.question: Marcus transfers stock worth $50,000 to his daughter in exchange for her car worth $20,000. What is the amount of the gift?

options.A: $0 because it was a bona fide sale

questions.explanation: When property is transferred for less than full consideration, the gift is the excess of the FMV of property given over the FMV of property received: $50,000 - $20,000 = $30,000 gift. This $30,000 would then be reduced by the annual exclusion to determine the taxable gift.
questions.tip: Gift amount = FMV of property transferred - FMV of consideration received.

questions.question: Bob inherited stock from his father who died on March 15. The father had purchased the stock for $10,000, it was worth $80,000 on the date of death, and $85,000 six months later. The executor did not elect the alternate valuation date. What is Bob's basis in the stock?
questions.explanation: Inherited property receives a basis equal to its fair market value at the date of death (or alternate valuation date if elected). Since no alternate valuation was elected, Bob's basis is the date of death value of $80,000. The original cost basis of $10,000 is irrelevant.
questions.tip: Inherited property = stepped-up (or stepped-down) basis to FMV at death. Gifted property = carryover basis.

questions.question: Maria received a gift of stock from her aunt. The aunt's basis was $40,000, and the FMV at the gift date was $35,000. Maria later sells the stock for $38,000. What is Maria's gain or loss?

options.A: $3,000 gain
options.B: $2,000 loss
options.C: $0 gain or loss
options.D: $3,000 loss

questions.explanation: When FMV at gift date is less than donor's basis, the donee has dual basis: donor's basis ($40,000) for gain, FMV at gift ($35,000) for loss. Since selling price of $38,000 is between these amounts, no gain or loss is recognized. This is the 'no-man's land' rule for depreciated gifts.
questions.tip: For gifts where FMV < donor's basis: gain uses carryover basis, loss uses FMV, and sales in between = zero gain/loss.

questions.question: The alternate valuation date election for estate tax purposes:

options.A: Can be elected for any estate regardless of effect on value
options.B: Values assets 6 months after death or date of earlier disposition
options.C: Values assets 12 months after death
options.D: Can be elected on an asset-by-asset basis

questions.explanation: The alternate valuation date is 6 months after death, or if property is distributed, sold, or otherwise disposed of within that period, the date of disposition. The election applies to the entire estate (not individual assets) and can only be elected if it reduces both the gross estate and the estate tax liability.
questions.tip: Alternate valuation = 6 months after death, entire estate, must reduce both value AND tax liability.

questions.question: Grandpa pays $50,000 directly to a university for his granddaughter's tuition and also gives her $18,000 cash for living expenses. What is Grandpa's total taxable gift?
questions.explanation: The $50,000 tuition payment qualifies for the unlimited educational exclusion (paid directly to the institution) and is not a taxable gift. The $18,000 cash gift is covered by the annual exclusion. Total taxable gift = $0. The educational exclusion is separate from and in addition to the annual exclusion.
questions.tip: Qualified tuition payments are unlimited AND separate from the annual exclusion. Room and board don't qualify.

questions.question: Under current law, for federal estate tax purposes, state death taxes paid are:

options.A: Allowed as a credit against federal estate tax
options.B: Allowed as a deduction from the gross estate
options.C: Not deductible and no credit allowed
options.D: Deductible only if the estate is under the exemption amount

questions.explanation: State death taxes are currently allowed as a deduction from the gross estate, not as a credit. The state death tax credit was phased out and replaced with the deduction. This change increased the effective federal estate tax burden for estates in states with estate or inheritance taxes.
questions.tip: The state death tax credit was repealed—now it's a deduction, which is less valuable than a dollar-for-dollar credit.

questions.question: A decedent's estate has the following: gross estate $15 million, funeral expenses $50,000, administration costs $150,000, debts $300,000, and charitable bequests $1 million. What is the taxable estate before applying the marital deduction?
questions.explanation: Taxable estate = Gross estate - Deductions. Deductions = Funeral ($50,000) + Administration ($150,000) + Debts ($300,000) + Charitable ($1,000,000) = $1,500,000. Taxable estate = $15,000,000 - $1,500,000 = $13,500,000.
questions.tip: Estate deductions: expenses (funeral, admin), debts, losses, charitable, and marital. Calculate step by step.

questions.question: When the first spouse dies with a $10 million estate and a $13.61 million exemption in 2024, the deceased spousal unused exclusion (DSUE) amount available to the surviving spouse is:

options.B: $3.61 million
options.C: $10 million
options.D: $13.61 million

questions.explanation: The DSUE is the unused portion of the deceased spouse's exclusion: $13.61 million - $10 million = $3.61 million. This amount is 'portable' to the surviving spouse if elected on a timely filed estate tax return (Form 706). The surviving spouse can use their own exemption plus the DSUE.
questions.tip: DSUE = Decedent's unused exemption. Requires timely Form 706 election, even if no tax is due.

questions.question: In a 'net gift' arrangement, the donee agrees to pay:

options.A: The donor's income tax on the gift
options.B: Any gift tax resulting from the transfer
options.C: The carrying costs of the property
options.D: The annual exclusion amount to the donor

questions.explanation: A net gift is a gift where the donee agrees to pay any gift tax owed. The gift tax is treated as consideration, reducing the amount of the gift. This creates a circular calculation since the gift tax depends on the gift amount, which depends on the gift tax paid.
questions.tip: Net gift reduces the taxable gift because the donee paying the tax is treated as consideration received by the donor.

questions.question: David transferred his home to his son but retained the right to live in it for life. At David's death, the home's FMV is $800,000. What is included in David's gross estate?

options.A: $0 because the transfer was completed during life
options.B: The actuarial value of the life estate
options.C: The value of the remainder interest

questions.explanation: Under Section 2036, if the decedent retained a life estate or the right to income from transferred property, the entire fair market value of the property at death is included in the gross estate. This 'string' pulls the property back into the estate despite the earlier transfer.
questions.tip: Section 2036: Retained life estate or income right = full FMV included in estate. The gift was 'incomplete' for estate purposes.

questions.question: The gift tax is computed on:

options.A: Only the current year's taxable gifts
options.B: Cumulative lifetime taxable gifts using current year rates
options.C: Cumulative lifetime taxable gifts using rates in effect when each gift was made
options.D: Total gifts made without regard to annual exclusions

questions.explanation: The gift tax is calculated on cumulative lifetime taxable gifts using current year rates. Tax on current year gifts is computed by calculating the tentative tax on all cumulative gifts and subtracting the tentative tax on prior year gifts. This ensures the progressive rate structure applies to cumulative giving.
questions.tip: Gift tax is cumulative. Current year tax = Tax on total cumulative gifts - Tax on prior cumulative gifts.

questions.question: Section 2032A special use valuation allows real property to be valued based on its:

options.A: Highest and best use
options.B: Actual use for farming or closely held business
options.C: Historical cost adjusted for inflation
options.D: Average of highest and actual use values

questions.explanation: Special use valuation under Section 2032A allows qualifying real property used in farming or a closely held business to be valued based on its actual use rather than its highest and best use. This can significantly reduce estate values for family farms and businesses, but comes with recapture rules if the use changes.
questions.tip: 2032A is for family farms and businesses—must continue qualified use or face recapture of tax savings.

questions.question: A transfer to a revocable trust is treated for gift tax purposes as:

options.A: A completed gift in the year of transfer
options.B: A completed gift when the trust becomes irrevocable
options.C: Not a gift because the grantor retains control
options.D: A split gift requiring annual returns

questions.explanation: A revocable transfer is not a completed gift because the grantor retains the power to revest the property. A gift is complete only when the donor has parted with dominion and control. When the trust becomes irrevocable (including at grantor's death), the transfer becomes complete.
questions.tip: No completed gift if donor can revoke. Gift becomes complete when power to revoke terminates.

questions.question: Thomas transferred ownership of a $2 million life insurance policy on his life to an irrevocable trust 2 years before his death. At death, the policy proceeds are:

options.A: Excluded from the gross estate because ownership was transferred
options.B: Included in the gross estate at the $2 million face value
options.C: Included at the policy's cash surrender value at transfer
options.D: Partially included based on the time of ownership

questions.explanation: Under Section 2035, life insurance transferred within 3 years of death is pulled back into the gross estate at its full face value. This special rule applies only to life insurance and certain other transfers that would have been included under Sections 2036-2038. The transfer occurred only 2 years before death, so the full $2 million is included.
questions.tip: The 3-year rule primarily catches life insurance transfers. Most other gifts are not pulled back after 3 years.

questions.question: The generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax applies to:

options.A: All transfers to grandchildren
options.B: Transfers that skip a generation where the transferee is at least 2 generations below the transferor
options.C: Only testamentary transfers, not lifetime gifts
options.D: Transfers to anyone more than 10 years younger than the transferor

questions.explanation: The GST tax applies to transfers to skip persons—those at least two generations below the transferor (like grandchildren when a child is living). It's designed to prevent families from avoiding one level of transfer tax by skipping a generation. The tax applies to both lifetime and testamentary transfers.
questions.tip: GST prevents wealthy families from giving to grandchildren to avoid estate tax at the children's level.

questions.question: A grandparent creates a trust that will pay income to a child for life, then principal to grandchildren. This is an example of a:

options.A: Direct skip
options.B: Taxable termination
options.C: Taxable distribution
options.D: Qualified terminable interest property trust

questions.explanation: A taxable termination occurs when an interest in a trust terminates (such as the child's death) and skip persons (grandchildren) become the beneficiaries. A direct skip is an outright transfer to a skip person. A taxable distribution is a distribution from a trust to a skip person during the trust's existence.
questions.tip: GST types: Direct skip (outright), Taxable termination (at death/end of interest), Taxable distribution (during trust).

questions.question: A decedent dies in 2024 with a taxable estate of $15 million and made $2 million in adjusted taxable gifts during life. Using a simplified 40% flat rate and $13.61 million exemption, what is the estate tax liability?
questions.explanation: Tax base = Taxable estate + Adjusted taxable gifts = $15M + $2M = $17M. Tentative tax at 40% = $6.8M. Unified credit on $13.61M exemption = $5.444M. Estate tax = $6.8M - $5.444M = $1.356M. (Note: Actual computation uses graduated rates, but 40% applies at these levels.)
questions.tip: Estate tax: Tax on (taxable estate + adjusted taxable gifts) - unified credit - gift tax paid. Gifts are added back.

questions.question: Section 6166 allows deferral of estate tax payments when:

options.A: The estate includes any real property
options.B: The estate lacks liquidity to pay taxes
options.C: A closely held business interest exceeds 35% of the adjusted gross estate
options.D: The surviving spouse elects to defer payment

questions.explanation: Section 6166 allows estates with a closely held business interest exceeding 35% of the adjusted gross estate to defer estate tax payments attributable to the business interest. The tax can be paid in installments over up to 14 years, with only interest due for the first 4 years.
questions.tip: Section 6166: 35% test for closely held business, up to 14 years to pay, special 2% interest rate on deferred tax.

questions.question: A Qualified Domestic Trust (QDOT) is required when:

options.A: Property passes to a surviving spouse who is a U.S. citizen
options.B: Property passes to a surviving spouse who is not a U.S. citizen and the marital deduction is desired
options.C: Property passes to qualified charities
options.D: The estate claims the alternate valuation date

questions.explanation: The unlimited marital deduction is not available for transfers to a non-citizen spouse unless the property passes through a QDOT. The QDOT must have at least one U.S. trustee, and estate tax is imposed when principal is distributed to the spouse or at the spouse's death.
questions.tip: Non-citizen spouse = no marital deduction unless QDOT is used. The QDOT defers (not eliminates) the estate tax.

questions.question: A Crummey power in an irrevocable trust allows the annual gift tax exclusion by:

options.A: Converting the trust to a grantor trust
options.B: Giving beneficiaries a temporary right to withdraw contributions
options.C: Making the trust revocable for a limited period
options.D: Allowing the trustee to distribute income annually

questions.explanation: Crummey powers give trust beneficiaries a temporary right (typically 30-60 days) to withdraw their share of contributions. This converts what would be a future interest (not eligible for annual exclusion) into a present interest. The beneficiary rarely exercises the power, but its existence qualifies the gift.
questions.tip: Crummey = temporary withdrawal right = present interest = annual exclusion. Must give actual notice to beneficiaries.

questions.question: If a decedent held a general power of appointment over trust assets at death:

options.A: Only the portion actually appointed is included in the estate
options.B: The entire value of the appointive property is included in the estate
options.C: Nothing is included because the trust is a separate entity
options.D: Only the value as of the date the power was granted is included

questions.explanation: Property subject to a general power of appointment (power to appoint to oneself, one's estate, creditors, or creditors of one's estate) is included in the gross estate at fair market value, whether or not the power is exercised. A limited or special power does not cause inclusion.
questions.tip: General power = estate inclusion. Limited power (can't appoint to self/estate/creditors) = no estate inclusion.

questions.question: Which of the following interests is most likely to qualify for valuation discounts for gift or estate tax purposes?

options.A: 100% ownership of publicly traded stock
options.B: A 30% interest in a family limited partnership
options.C: Cash in a bank account
options.D: A remainder interest in a personal residence

questions.explanation: A minority interest in a family limited partnership (FLP) may qualify for both minority/lack of control discounts (because the holder cannot control entity decisions) and lack of marketability discounts (because there's no ready market for the interest). These discounts can reduce the gift/estate tax value significantly.
questions.tip: FLP discounts: minority discount (no control) + marketability discount (no market) = potentially 25-40% total discount.

questions.question: In a Grantor Retained Annuity Trust (GRAT), the taxable gift is:

options.A: The full fair market value of the property transferred
options.B: The present value of the annuity payments
options.C: The present value of the remainder interest passing to beneficiaries
options.D: Zero because the grantor retains all rights

questions.explanation: The taxable gift in a GRAT is the present value of the remainder interest—what beneficiaries will receive after the annuity term. The higher the annuity payments and longer the term, the smaller the remainder (taxable gift). A 'zeroed-out' GRAT has minimal taxable gift while potentially transferring appreciation tax-free.
questions.tip: GRAT: Taxable gift = FMV of property - PV of retained annuity. Goal is to minimize remainder value at creation.

questions.question: When a parent makes an interest-free loan of $500,000 to a child, the gift tax consequence is:

options.A: No gift because it is a loan, not a transfer
options.B: A gift of the full $500,000
options.C: A gift equal to the foregone interest using the AFR
options.D: A gift only if the loan is not repaid

questions.explanation: Under Section 7872, interest-free or below-market loans result in imputed interest. The foregone interest (difference between AFR and rate charged) is treated as a gift from lender to borrower and interest income to the lender. For demand loans, this is computed annually.
questions.tip: Below-market loans: foregone interest = gift from lender and interest income to lender. Use AFR as the benchmark.

questions.question: A QTIP trust qualifies for the marital deduction if the surviving spouse:

options.A: Is given the power to appoint the property to anyone
options.B: Receives all income at least annually for life
options.C: Can withdraw principal at any time
options.D: Is named as trustee of the trust

questions.explanation: A QTIP trust qualifies for the marital deduction if the surviving spouse is entitled to all income at least annually for life and no person has the power to appoint property to anyone other than the surviving spouse during the spouse's life. The executor must elect QTIP treatment. At the spouse's death, the property is included in the spouse's estate.
questions.tip: QTIP = income to spouse for life, no one else gets principal during spouse's life, included in survivor's estate.
